children.prompt: Prepare the Acid Vent Scrubber for maintenance.
Supersedes Issue
K

children.text: This procedure has been reviewed as part of the 3 year review with no changes.

This procedure revision falls under the Category 2 listed below (indicate 1, 2, or 3)

  1. This procedure modification is the result of MOC (list MOC number)         ).
  2. This procedure modification is the sole result of clarifications, additional information, or grammatical corrections.  (GOP-G-6. II.A.1). 
  3. This procedure modification is the result of a change to the "instructional elements" of the standard operating procedure.  (Example:  Adding, Deleting, Modifying, or Switching the order of  operating instructions). Complete the two items below.

Technical Basis for Proposed Change: None

Impact of change of safety and Health: None

children.action: Prepare the Acid Vent Scrubber for maintenance.

children.title: This procedure establishes a safe uniform method to:

children.action: Acid Vent Scrubber, FA-391
Packed Tower, D-104
Slurry Sump Tank, TK-21

children.title: The Acid Vent Scrubber system equipment:

children.action: Caustic can cause severe burns to eyes and skin. In case of skin contact, flush the affected area with water for at least 15 minutes. Clothing that has come in contact with caustic should be removed and not worn again until thoroughly washed. In case of contact with the eyes, flush with water for 15 minutes and report to Medical.

Acid gases contain hydrochloric acid (HCl) which is a respirator irritant and can cause lung damage.  Wear respirators with integral eye protection and the appropriate acid gas cartridges if the piping associated with the scrubber has to be opened.

children.title: Acid gases will attack stainless steel.  Never use a stainless steel alloy in contact with acid gas.  This includes pressure and level gauges and associated piping.

All personnel are required to wear safety glasses, hard hats, ear protection, and a radio in all outside process areas in the Flexinol Department.  Flexinol Department personnel and support staff are required to wear flame retardant clothing in all outside areas in the department.  Anyone entering the area or inside the “Limited” and “Restricted” access zones in the tank farm will be required to wear flame retardant clothing.  Flexinol Department support staff who perform duties normally associated with operators, mechanics, or contractor craft and labor personnel are required to wear flame retardant clothing.  Flame retardant clothing options are flame retardant coveralls or flame retardant pant/shirt combination with long sleeves.

notes: Complete Caustic PPE consists of the following: Chemical goggles, Face shield, Impermeable clothing (Rain coat or Slicker suit), Rubber gloves, Rubber boots.

children.action: Routine Samples caught in bottles inside of the contained sample cabinet do not require additional PPE (goggles, rubber gloves) unless caustic is over flowed or splashed on the bottle. In that circumstance, rubber gloves should be used when handling the bottle.
Routine Samples caught at dedicated sampling points without containment (Spent Caustic) but with double block needle valves to control pressure require Chemical goggles and rubber gloves.
Non-routine samples caught at bleed valves (No needle valve to control flow); Complete Caustic PPE will be used
Any “first break” on piping/equipment containing caustic requires Complete Caustic PPE.
If the pump has been flushed with water, drained, and is free of pressure per procedure; Chemical goggles and Rubber gloves can be used.
If the pump cannot be flushed or drains are plugged: Complete Caustic PPE will be used.
Opening pump suction piping for strainer basket cleaning.
Complete Caustic PPE will be used.
Blowing down plugged transmitters.
Complete Caustic PPE will be used.
Non-routine work opening piping or flanges.

children.title: PPE requirements. There are different situations that will require different levels of PPE usage. Additional PPE should always be used in abnormal situations.
Much of the piping in the caustic supply system is steam-traced. Be aware of hot steam tracing to avoid thermal burns.

children.action: Trip sprinkler number 25 for FA-391 and TK-21.
Call Extension 616; give the nature of the emergency, building number, and phone number.  Do not hang up until the operator clearly understands.  Meet the fire truck at the nearest street.
Call Power and Services Department and report the use of fire water.

Do not move injured personnel unless their life is in danger.  Call Extension 616; give the nature of the emergency, building number, and phone number.  Do not hang up until the operator clearly understands.  Meet the ambulance at the nearest street.
Emergencies must be taken care of without panic.  The safe way is a thinking way.

children.title: In case of spill, fire, or personnel injury:

children.text: <u><font face="Time New Roman" size="4">Purpose of FA-391</font></u>

children.action: FA-391 is an 8-foot x 40-foot tank with a flat bottom and a conical top.  It is constructed of fiberglass reinforced plastic and has a maximum allowable working pressure of 8 psig.  The relief valve is set to relieve at 6 psig.  Figure 1 is a graphic layout of FA-391.
Acid gas containing HCl enters at the bottom of FA-391 and passes up through it.

Several banks of nozzles spray the caustic scrubbing fluid downward through the upcoming acid gas, and a chemical reaction between the sodium hydroxide and the hydrochloric acid neutralizes the acid, creating NaCL and water.
The neutralized acid gas passes through a mist eliminator pad to remove any entrained droplets of the caustic and then passes out of FA-391.
The caustic scrubbing solution collects in the base of FA-391, where it is pumped back up to the spray nozzles.

children.text: FA-391 Safety Critical Interlock (I-1296) may only be defeated for the following reasons:

children.action: Instrumentation on FA-391 monitors the level of the scrubbing solution in the base and the pH of the scrubbing solution.  Partially spent caustic is bled out of the recirculating scrubbing solution and fresh caustic is added to it to maintain a constant pH.

children.text: FA-391 Safety Critical Interlock (I-1296) may only be defeated for the following reasons:

children.action: Maintenance reasons (calibrations, etc.).

notes: OPERATOR MUST MONITOR EQUIPMENT CONTINUOUSLY WHILE IT IS ON DEFEAT.

children.cause: Exceeding FA-391 high-high level or high-high pressure could result in a release of Acid gas and caustic in the area.
children.effect: Acid gas is extremely irritating to the eyes and respiratory tract.  Inhalation of Acid gas can cause delayed lung injury and is fatal at elevated exposure.

children.action: Testing of interlocks and alarms.

SAFETY SYSTEM:  FA-391 Safety Critical Interlock (I-1296) shuts down FA-391 if any of the following conditions exist:  High-High Level, High-High Pressure, or any of the hand switches are tripped.  Documentation records for all Safety Critical Instrumentation will be maintained in the Plant Equipment Global Access System (PEGAS).  The department CSM will normally perform the tests for Safety Critical Instruments in the department using the Stored Plan maintained in PEGAS.  However, operators may perform the functional testing of the alarm or interlock using the interlock checkout procedure located in PEGAS.  The PEGAS system will prompt the department when these checks are due.  An MOC will be required to change a Safety Critical Interlock setpoint.  For more information see GR-12-58.  Bypassing or suppressing Safety Critical Interlocks and alarms will be restricted to the minimum time necessary to perform the required testing or maintenance, or where bypassing is a necessary part of equipment or unit start-up.  In the unusual event that a Safety Critical Interlock or alarm must be bypassed or suppressed during unsteady state conditions and this is not addressed by a standard operating procedure, the action to bypass or suppress must be approved by the department superintendent, the first-line supervisor, and the Plant Protection on-call representative.  In all cases where no standard operating procedure exists, a safework plan must be developed for the temporary mode of operation.  Employee review with all affected employees must also be documented on the safework plan.  The employee review of the safework plan can be documented by a shift supervisor in their electronic logbook write-ups.  A reading in the affected data routes will come up every 2 hours asking if any Safety Critical Interlocks are on defeat.  The Safety Critical Interlock Summary Screen will compile all of these into one location for easy and quick access.

children.prompt: Auto Action

children.action: Alarm Summary:

notes:
Before starting the procedure, confirm the following items: 

  • Instrumentation and Control Systems that have been worked on have been checked out. 
  • Leak testing has been performed where applicable. 
  • After leak test, all plugs have been installed and bleed valves on closed. 
  • Process tracing, if applicable, has been checked out. 
  • Printed procedures and/or start-up checklists will be used during the preparation for maintenance to ensure all steps are completed.

children.action: ISOLATE XV-0001 on the Acid Vent Header, upstream of the scrubber.
ISOLATE the caustic feed by closing FCV-2016
ISOLATE the first butterfly valve downstream of the strainer on the caustic re-circulation line.
OPEN the globe valve upstream of FV-2013 on the spent caustic line from the re-circulation line.
CLOSE the gate valve on the process water line directly upstream of the Slurry Sump Tank.

START one of the re-circulation pumps, and allow the tank to pump down to the Spent Caustic Tanks until reaching the low-low level in the Slurry Sump Tank. Once the low-low level is reached, the pump will automatically shut off.
ISOLATE the first butterfly valve upstream of the pump being used.
OPEN the butterfly valve on the 6” drain line from the Slurry Sump Tank.
DRAIN the remainder of the tank to the sump.
CLOSE the butterfly valve on the 6” drain line.
OPEN the globe valve on the water line to the Slurry Sump Tank.
FILL the Slurry Sump Tank to a level of 3’ with process water.
CLOSE the globe valve on the water line
OPEN the butterfly valve directly upstream of the pump to be used.
OPEN the first butterfly valve upstream of the strainer on the re-circulation line.
TURN on the pump and allow the water to re-circulate through the tank for 20-30 minutes.
CLOSE the butterfly valve upstream of the pump being used, and open the 6” butterfly valve on the tank drain line.
DRAIN the water to the sump.

notes: Once a neutral pH is reached, the tank, pumps, and re-circulation line are cleaned and/or ready for maintenance.

children.action: VERIFY this by checking the pH at the bleed valve on the suction side of the pump.

notes: For cleanup of the Packed Scrubber, the contents (any liquid level) must be pushed back through the Slurry Sump Tank in order to be routed to the Spent Caustic Tanks.

children.action: ISOLATE the caustic feed by closing FCV-2017 on the caustic feed line.
CLOSE the 1” plug valves immediately downstream of FV-2025 and FV-2024 to isolate the process water feed to the Scrubber.
ENSURE that the 3” plug valve on the Packed Scrubber drain line is closed.
ISOLATE the 4” globe valve immediately downstream of PI-2012 on the caustic re-circulation line.
ENSURE that the ¾” plug valves on both sides of EV-2014 are open, allowing flow into the Slurry Sump Tank.

ENSURE that the 8” butterfly valve directly upstream of the Basket Strainer is closed, and the 2” globe valve on the Spent Caustic Line is open, directing flow to the Spent Caustic Tanks. Use one of the Packed Tower Pumps to pump the liquid level from the Packed Scrubber to the Slurry Sump Tank.
CLOSE the 4” butterfly valve directly downstream of the tank on the re-circulation line.
OPEN the 3” plug valve on the drain line and drain the remaining contents to the sump.
CLOSE the 3” plug valve on the drain line.
OPEN the 1” plug valves on the two process water lines to the Packed Scrubber and allow water to fill the tank to a level of 36”.
CLOSE the 1” plug valves on the process water feed lines.
OPEN the 4” butterfly valve directly downstream of the Packed Scrubber on the re-circulation line to the pump.
CLOSE the ¾” plug valve directly upstream of EV-2014 to stop flow to the Slurry Sump Tank.
OPEN the 4” globe valve immediately downstream of PI-2012 on the re-circulation line.
USE one of the pumps to re-circulate the water for one hour.
CLOSE the butterfly valve upstream of the pump being used.
OPEN the 3” plug valve on the drain line and drain the water to the sump.
REPEAT these water re-circulation steps until a pH of 7-9 is reached in the tank.
VERIFY this by checking the pH at the bleed valve on the suction side of the pump.

children.prompt: Sensor at tank farm sewer hub

children.text:
<font size="4" face="Time New Roman">If any one of the sensors detects an HCL an HCl concentration above its high alarm limit, an alarm will sound on the DCS.  If any one of the sensors detects an HCl concentration above its high-high alarm limit, an alarm will sound on
the DCS, personnel will leave the immediate areas, and the sprinklers will
trip at FA-391 and TK-21.  Press the reset button to turn the sprinklers off.</font>

children.action: SAFETY SYSTEM: There are twelve HCl sensors located in the field. There are nine sensors located around FA-391, two sensors located at TK-21, and one located at the tank farm sewer hub. Alarm limits for the HCl sensors are given below:
OPEN the plug valve on the drain line and drain contents to the sump.
CONNECT a utility hose from the service water drop to a connection on the stack.
FLUSH the stack with water and drain it to the sump until a neutral pH (7-9) is reached in the stack.
REMOVE the outboard bearing bracket from the Caustic Recirculation Pump.
